Anderson-Teixeira, Erika Gonzalez-Akre, Stuart Davies, William McShea, Alyssa Terrell, Michael Scott, Caroline Kittle, Ian McGregor 2018

1 Chapter 1: Introduction Forests make up 45% of terrestrial carbon (Bonan 2008 and Stovall et al. 2018). The amount of carbon held in by trees can have a negative impact due to the emissions that are released into the air caused by deforestation. The rise in carbon emissions is attributed to the rise in tree mortality. Mortality is one of the most important causes of forest dynamics (Gonzalez-Akre et al. 2016), as it can influnce the number and distribution of woody species that are found in an area. It can also be detrimental because tree mortality can be used as an indication of climate change (Gonzalez-Akre 2016). In 1974, the Smithsonian purchased a piece of land, known as the Remount Depot. Shortly after the purchase, the land became the Conservation Research Center.The Front Royal site of the National Zoological Park is ~1,296 hectares (3,500 acres) and combined with research and academic facilities, forestry, pastures, and animal enclosures (ASK ERIKA OR KRISTA HOW TO CITE THE CULTURAL RESOUCE ASSESSMENT - Ayers et al. 2007). </section> </div> </div> </div> SCBI: Plot Book <div class="book-summary"> <nav role="navigation"> SCBI: Plot Book 1 Chapter 1: Introduction 2 Chapter 2: Physical Environment 3 Chapter 3: Methods 4 Chapter 4: Tree Species 4.1 Adoxaceae 4.1.1 Sambucus canadensis (American black elderberry) 4.1.2 Viburnum acerifolium (Mapleleaf viburnum) 4.1.3 Viburnum prunifolium (Black haw) 4.1.4 Viburnum recognitum (Southern arrowood) 4.2 Annonaceae 4.2.1 Asimina triloba (Pawpaw) 4.3 Aquifoliaceae 4.3.1 Ilex verticillata (Common winterberry) 4.4 Berberidaceae 4.4.1 Berberis thunbergii (Japanese barberry) 4.5 Betulaceae 4.5.1 Carpinus caroliniana (American hornbeam) 4.5.2 Corylus americana (American hazelnut) 4.6 Cannabaceae 4.6.1 Celtis occidentalis (Hackberry) 4.7 Caprifoliaceae 4.7.1 Lonicera maackii (Bush honeysuckle) 4.8 Celastraceae 4.8.1 Euonymus alatus (Burning bush) 4.9 Cornaceae 4.9.1 Cornus alternifolia (Alternate leaf dogwood) 4.10 Cornaceae 4.10.1 Cornus florida (Flowering dogwood) 4.11 Ebenaceae 4.11.1 Diospyros virginiana (Persimmon) 4.12 Elaeagnaceae 4.12.1 Elaeagnus umbellata (Autumn olive) 4.13 Fabaceae 4.13.1 Cercis canadensis (Eastern redbud) 4.14 Fabaceae 4.14.1 Robinia pseudoacacia (Black locust) 4.15 Fagaceae 4.15.1 Castanea dentata (American chestnut) 4.15.2 Fagus grandifolia (American beech) 4.15.3 Quercus alba (White oak) 4.15.4 Quercus coccinea (Scarlet oak) 4.15.5 Quercus falcata (Southern red oak) 4.15.6 Quercus michauxii (Swamp chestnut oak) 4.15.7 Quercus muehlenbergii (Chinkapin oak) 4.15.8 Quercus prinus (Chestnut oak) 4.15.9 Quercus rubra (Northern red oak) 4.15.10 Quercus velutina (Black oak) 4.16 Hamamelidaceae 4.16.1 Hamamelis virginiana (American witchhazel) 4.17 Juglandaceae 4.17.1 Carya cordiformis (Bitternut hickory) 4.17.2 Carya glabra (Pignut hickory) 4.17.3 Carya ovalis (Red hickory) 4.17.4 Carya sp. 2 Chapter 2: Physical Environment The dynamic plot is located at the Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute (SCBI) in Virginia, U.S.A (38°53’36.6“N, 78°08’43.4”W) with the elevation ranging from 273m to 338m (Gozalez-Akre et al. 2016). The research site is a temperate deciduous forest within a 25.6-hectare plot set up 640m by 400m (Bourg et al. 2013). This part of the document will be describing the research site. This part should include climate (include graph used in mortality paper), topography (graphs created by Ian), and soil information I think it would be beneficial to include figure 2 from Stovall et al. 2018 “The top 10 domintant species contributing over 80% of biomass within the ForestGEO forest as estimated using the Chonjnacky et al. (2014) equations.” </section> </div> </div> </div>
